data.title: What‚Äôs it Like Living in Lebanon TN? üè° | Complete Guide to Moving to Lebanon Tennessee
data.meta_description: Are you thinking about moving to Lebanon, TN? üööHere's an ULTIMATE guide for everything you need to know about living in the family-friendly city of Lebanon!
data.text:
Last Updated on:

As a county seat for Wilson County, TN, the city of Lebanon is known for being home to Cumberland University, and its nickname is ‚ÄúCedar City.‚Äù Lebanon was incorporated in 1801 and got its name from the ‚ÄúCedars of Lebanon.‚Äù Moving to Lebanon is a one-of-a-kind choice if you‚Äôre looking for a nice place to live, plant your roots, and raise a family ‚Äì it‚Äôs a perfect place for a variety of professions and people of all ages.

Where Is Lebanon?

Lebanon is in Wilson County, part of Middle Tennessee and the Nashville metro area. It‚Äôs bordered by Mt. Juliet to the east. Lebanon has plenty of beautiful parks and camping grounds, like Nashville East/Lebanon KOA Journey, and other local places to explore.

The closest city to Lebanon is Nashville. From Lebanon to Nashville, it‚Äôs 32 miles. When it comes to public transportation, the only option that‚Äôs directly in the city of Lebanon is the Music City Star commuter train. If needed, there are additional transportation options that are specific to the cities and designated areas.

Lebanon Population & Demographics

The population of Lebanon is 37,471, and the population density is 945 people per square mile. Since 2010, the population in Lebanon has increased by 11,281 residents.

When it comes to notable people from Lebanon, you have Ben Hayslip, Coco Jones, and Kenny Winfree.

Lebanon demographics:

74% White, 7% Hispanic, 2% Asian, 5% Biracial, 11% African American, 1% Other

Gender breakdown: 53% female and 47% male

5.8% foreign-born Population

Median household income: $60,582, which is higher than the state median household income of $58,516

Median age: 36 years old

Educational attainment: 30% bachelor‚Äôs degree or higher

The total crime rate in Lebanon is 3,370 per 100k people, which is 43.6% higher than the national average. The violent crime rate is 571 per 100k people, which is 47.2% higher than the national average (but 15.1% lower than the state average), and the property crime rate is 2,799 per 100k people, which is 42.9% higher than the national average. While the crime rate in Lebanon might be higher than the national average, there are plenty of safe neighborhoods.

With the Lebanon Police Department, there are a total of 128 employees (100 of which are sworn officers) that help to serve and protect this Tennessee city.

Cost of Living in Lebanon

The cost of living in Lebanon, TN, is 3.2% higher than the national average. Most categories are on par or even below the national average, but the housing category makes the cost of living higher than the rest of the United States. According to the Economic Policy Institute, a family of four in Wilson County will need to make $84,076 annually to live comfortably in Lebanon.

The following information is based on Nashville, TN, since it‚Äôs the biggest city closest to Lebanon, TN.

Typical Lebanon Living Expenses

Meal, inexpensive restaurant: $18.25

Domestic beer (1 pint draught): $5.50

Milk (regular, 1 gallon): $3.91

Bread (1 loaf): $3.40

Oranges (1 pound): $1.77

Apples (1 pound): $2.70

Beef round (1 pound): $7.72

Eggs (regular, 12): $4.30

Average cost of gasoline per gallon: $3.33

Fitness club (Per Month, 1 Adult): $60.75

Average Lebanon utilities per month: $300

Source: Numbeo

When it comes to real estate, the median sale price in Lebanon is $375,000, and the average sale price per square footage is $200. There are plenty of Lebanon, TN homes for sale, that are perfect for settling down. For the price breakdown of the different types of properties are the following:

Single-Family: $417,915

Condo: $295,990

Townhouse: $329,990

According to RentCafe, the average rent in Lebanon, TN, is $1,384 per month. There are plenty of beautiful apartments available for rent in Lebanon.

Lebanon Neighborhoods | Where to Live in Lebanon

Here are some of the best Lebanon neighborhoods.

Stonebridge | Resort-Style Community In Lebanon

While Stonebridge isn‚Äôt considered an age-restricted community, it‚Äôs popular for active adults. There are a variety of property styles, and this resort-style community is perfect for all ages. You can find everything from Townhomes, Villas, Single-Family homes, and Condos. Nearby, you can find the Providence Marketplace, movie theaters, and local parks like Lebanon State Park. The average price ranges from around $350,000 and $537,000+.

Plantation South | Affordable Single-Family Homes

Plantation South has beautiful single-family homes, and they are affordable. The price for homes in Plantation South is usually between $346,000 and $600,000+, but it can depend on the size of the house. There are plenty of highly-rated schools within the neighborhood, like Coles Ferry Elementary School and Lebanon High School.

Lebanon Weather & Climate

The climate in Lebanon, TN, is a humid subtropical climate (Cfa). The spring and summer months are muggy and hot, and the average temperature in Lebanon can range from the low-70s and the low-90s. The fall and winter months are wet, cloudy, and cold, and the temperature can range from the mid-40s to the low 50s.

Lebanon receives an average of 44.5 inches per year and 5.6 inches of snow per year, and can experience extreme weather patterns such as tornadoes, hurricanes, and flooding. If you‚Äôre planning on coming to Lebanon, the best time is between May and June and then again in the later part of July and October.

Things to Do in Lebanon

In Lebanon, TN, they have a variety of shopping malls to choose from, but the most popular ones are the Cedar Square Shopping Center and the Lebanon Center.

Wilson County Fair

With a variety of competitions, exhibitions, live music entertainment, food booths, and rides, the Tennessee State Fair is a family-favorite annual event. This community favorite event brings the residents together and celebrates Tennessee‚Äôs traditions.

945 E Baddour Pkwy, Lebanon, TN 37087 (615) 443-2626

Don Fox Community Park

The Don Fox Park is a family-friendly and kid-friendly attraction with a variety of amenities like a grill, pavilion, picnic areas, a swimming pool, and a walking track. If you plan on using the pavilion, you will need to make a reservation, and the price will be dependent upon how long you need it.

955 W Baddour Pkwy, Lebanon, TN 37087 (615) 449-0303

Fiddlers Grove Historic Village

Transport back into history with the Fiddlers Grove. It is a historical museum where you can walk through an old village with everything from the original buildings ranging from schools, a church, a general store, a blacksmith‚Äôs shop, a doctor‚Äôs office, a law office, and homes.

And there‚Äôs a variety of clubs at Fiddlers Grove, like the Antique Car Club, Arboretum & Gardens, Blacksmiths, and Model Railroad Club, to name a few.

945 E Baddour Pkwy, Lebanon, TN 37087 (615) 547-6111

The Lebanon Park and Recreational Department manages the parks throughout the city. To attend a community event, take a look at the Lebanon event calendar.

Additional Places To Visit In Lebanon

Capitol Theater

Jimmy Floyd Center Outdoor Pool

Pro Bowl West

Roxy Movie Theater

Sellars Farm State Archaeological Area

Lebanon Restaurants

Food is a love language that brings people together. Here are some of the best restaurants in Lebanon, TN!

Speedy Burrito

As one of the best Mexican restaurants in Lebanon, Speedy Burrito serves authentic Mexican food at an affordable price. Whether you enjoy burritos, tamales, quesadillas, tacos, or rice, you can find everything you love and more!

307 W Main St, Lebanon, TN 37087 (615) 784-4071

Shoney‚Äôs

Since 1947, Shoney‚Äôs has been a family-friendly and all-American restaurant in Lebanon, TN. With delicious and freshly prepared food, Shoney‚Äôs has gone from a small-town food joint to a franchise chain.

814 S Cumberland St, Lebanon, TN 37087 (615) 444-2447

Demos‚Äô Restaurant

As a family-owned Lebanon restaurant, Demos‚Äô Restaurant serves authentic Italian food with fresh ingredients. A few of the most popular menu items include Blackened Chicken Stuffed Potato, Fettuccine Imperial, and Lasagna. They have happy hour seven days a week, and daily lunch specials.

130 Legends Dr, Lebanon, TN 37087 (615) 443-4600

Jobs in Lebanon

The top employers in Lebanon, TN, include the City of Lebanon, Wilson County Schools, and the Wilson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office. When it comes to the top industries in Lebanon include Education, Distribution Centers, and Law Enforcement.

The average salary in Lebanon is $61,000, and the average hourly rate is $17.78, according to Payscale.

If you plan on relocating to Lebanon without a job, there are 17,800+ jobs available on Indeed within a 25-mile radius. You can also find available jobs with the government of Lebanon.

Lebanon Schools

Lebanon, TN, is part of the Wilson County School System. Some of the schools available to the students who live in Lebanon include Gladeville Elementary, Mt Juliet Middle, and Lebanon High School. The local library is the Lebanon-Wilson County Public Library.

There are plenty of top colleges and universities near Lebanon, TN, and some of the top ones are Cumberland University, Trevecca Nazarene University, Lipscomb University, Middle Tennessee State University, and Vanderbilt University.

Lebanon Statistics & Information

Lebanon county: Wilson

Lebanon area: 39.7 square miles

Lebanon zip codes: 37087-37088 and 37090

Lebanon area code: 615

Lebanon elevation: 528 feet above sea level

Lebanon time zone: Eastern Standard Time (EST)

Closest airport: Nashville International Airport (BNA), 25 miles away

Map of Lebanon, TN

Explore more restaurants, amenities, shops, and places with this map of Lebanon, TN!
